content.text:
# Trinity Lutheran Church (Queens)

| locmapin     = New York City#New York#USA
| built        = 1926
| architect    = Corbusier, John William Cresswell; Conable, George
| architecture = Gothic Revival, Collegiate Gothic
| added        = May 29, 2008
| area         = less than one acre
| refnum       = 08000471
}}
Trinity Lutheran Church is a historic Lutheran church at 31-18 37th Street in Astoria, Queens, New York. It was designed by John William Cresswell Corbusier and overseen by architect George W. Conable (1866â€“1933). It was built in 1926 and is a one-story Collegiate Gothic style building. It is constructed of brick faced with coursed rubble aplite trimmed in cast stone. The front elevation features a recessed entry with a large window above, framed by two spires with ornate turrets. The interior is in a Gothic plan of nave and transepts.
It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2008.
Music
The church owns a 1927 Skinner pipe organ, which is still operational and used during Sunday services. The church also has a handbell choir which rings hymns, peals and processionals. Other musical activity at the church includes a choir, piano, cello and musical saw.
